Issues.Title: refactor(core): Omit listeners from out-of-zone scheduling when usingâ€¦
Issues.Body:
â€¦ ZoneJS (#55492)

In Angular today, a bound listener automatically marks the view for check. When using ZoneJS, these listeners are most often executed in the Angular Zone as well, so synchronization (`ApplicationRef.tick`) will eventually happen. _However_, developers can opt out of zone-patching for events in several ways, and often do this for very frequent listeners like `mousemove`, `resize`, and `scroll`. We do not want to break existing expectations that these are now "safe" events to have listeners for by automatically scheduling change detection regardless of whether the listener executed inside or outside the Angular zone.

In contrast, in order for developers to more easily transition to zoneless, we need to be able to ensure that components which are using `OnPush` are, for the most part, compatible with zoneless as well. Because listeners automatically mark the component for check, developers using `OnPush` did not/do not need to also call `ChangeDetectorRef.markForCheck` or a similar API. Unfortunately, this means that we need to consider the listener callbacks as a notification to schedule a `tick` when Zoneless is enabled. In the future, we would like to have an opt-out for this (i.e. signal components) since it's not really how we _want_ things to work.

Also includes the fix for #54919 that got reverted only because it was easier to revert the set of conflicting commits

Issues.Title: Angular 17 SSR: Slow server response time when using wildcard route
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

platform-server

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

We use Angular 17 SSR together with the CMS Storyblok in order to load routes dynamically. To approach this, we need to use the wildcard route ** in order to handle the loading of the requested Storyblok pages (done via slugs taken from the url path). The static site generation works as expected, however, the loading times of the static html page is very slow and takes around 1.5s.

After analysing various potential causes for the problem, we noticed that the wildcard route seems to be root of the issue. If we define a static route and load the static HTML page via the Storyblok JS Client server side, it is blazingly fast and only takes around 20ms. Alas, defining static routes is not really an option for us since our client needs to create pages dynamically on the CMS side.

The loading times differ by a factor of around 40, so it's a massive difference.

We created a small reproduction project with a very trivial HttpClient GET request to an open API to display a JSON on screen. Although the difference in loading times is not as huge as with our real project, it is still a lot and should suffice to illustrate to problem. (Difference by a factor of around 20)

Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

---

I completely disagree with the fact that feature requests are closed without an exhaustive explanation. This is actually the scope of angular-cli. So, reopen: #17318 

---

### Description

According to [Official Document](https://angular.io/guide/browser-support#polyfills), polyfills can only be included manually.

Sometimes we somehow use ESNext features like Array.prototype.flatMap but forget adding its polyfill into polyfills.ts, it accidentally breaks on some browsers.

### Describe the solution you'd like

In https://github.com/alauda, we are using [@alauda/custom-webpack](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@alauda/custom-webpack) which pipes babel-loader after @ngtools/webpack in webpack config, so that we get auto polyfilling successfully via @babel/preset-env.

So I'm suggesting to add auto polyfilling support into @angular/cli.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

If we can build all .ts via @ngtools/webpack with targeting esnext, then we can use babel to compiling all ES syntaxes totally but are able to get types metadata still at the same time.

Issues.Title: Script tags are not added to the child pages when build SSR project
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

In certain scenarios when we build an SSR project the child pages are not getting script tags injected, thus any interactions on that pages are impossible.

The only page the gets references to the main scripts is `index.html`.
___

If the app's root tag specified as a self-closing tag, then after building the project the app's root tag will wrap the script tags. Internal pages **won't get** main script tags injected.

_src/index.html_:
```html
<body>
  <app-performance-root />
</body>
```

_dist/\<project-name\>/browser/index.html_:
```html
<body>
  <app-performance-root>
    <script src="polyfills.js" type="module"></script>
    <script src="main.js" type="module"></script>
  </app-performance-root>
</body>
```

If the app's root tag specified as a "normal" html tag, then everythings builds in order. Internal pages **will get** main script tags injected.

_src/index.html_:
```html
<body>
  <app-performance-root></app-performance-root>
</body>
```

_dist/\<project-name\>/browser/index.html_:
```html
<body>
  <app-performance-root></app-performance-root>
  <script src="polyfills.js" type="module"></script>
  <script src="main.js" type="module"></script>
</body>
```

Issues.Title: fix(material/theming): remove shadow from system tokens
Issues.Body:
Switching the `shadow` token to point to a css variable breaks box-shadows for at least one component (card) but likely breaks elevation in general across all components.

Our box-shadows are generated by calling MDC mixin(s?) which expect the shadow color to be in a specific format. This breaks if we pass in a css variable (`var(--sys-shadow)`).

As a temporary fix, we should go back to using the hardcoded value for the `shadow` token.

In the long-term, we should copy MDC's mixin(s?) so that we have control over how the box-shadow's shadow color is being used.

Issues.Body:
The usage of more modern css (specifically color variable + opacity combination logic) breaks some applications.

This shouldn't be an issue since this is an opt-in feature, but the checks for whether to use this color + opacity logic were not strict enough. They only checked that the color was a css variable, but it turns out that some teams are already somehow passing in css variables into our system, so this check was not strict enough for those teams.
